Introduction 
Karynn, Gabriel, Wesley, Hadley and Elanor. 
What  
I was asked to speak about something I’ve recently studied or had on my mind. 
I’ve wrestled with these ideas for years now. This is the first time I’ve tried to bring them 
together in one place and explain them all at once. 
 
Paraphrase 
Joshua 24: 
14   Now therefore fear the LORD, and serve him in sincerity and in truth: and put 
away the gods which your fathers served...  
15... choose you this day whom ye will serve; ... as for me and my house, we will 
serve the LORD. 
 
Ultimately we choose what to believe. Faith is choosing to believe in the Gospel 
of Jesus Christ. In this talk I’ll interchange belief and faith in reference to this idea.  
 
Why do we need to choose faith in Christ? Why doesn’t everyone believe in Him 
and His Gospel? Why do people struggle in the gospel? Why do I believe?  
I’ve thought a lot about this. Bear with me, this is what I’ve come up with: It is 
because it is irrational to believe in Jesus Christ and His Gospel. 
 
● A definition of irrational is: not logical or reasonable. 
● A definition of rational is: based on or in accordance with reason or logic. 
 
 In contrast, through the muddy cloud of emotion, our brains want to rationalize, 
reason and logic everything. We want things to make sense. We want to know the 
answers to everything. Just a few relatable examples: 
 
When I was younger, my parents asked me to do a chore, or share with a sibling, 
or whatever, my first thought was, “Why? Why me?” 
 
I know the Jr high, and highschool students will relate to this. Whe

en I was younger, my parents asked me to do a chore, or share with a sibling, 
or whatever, my first thought was, “Why? Why me?” 
 
I know the Jr high, and highschool students will relate to this. When you’re in 
math class, and you’re asked to learn a new formula, or given homework, what is the 
most common thing to hear, “When are we ever going to use math?”

At work, I had a really nice boss. He’d often ask us to complete tasks that made 
no sense and wouldn’t lead to higher sales numbers. In my mind while completing the 
task I’d grumble “Why does he want me to do this?” 
 
It’s just our nature. 
 
We shouldn’t expect it to be any different in regards to believing in God. It’s part 
of our nature to have questions and as a result struggle with aspects of the gospel - and 
that’s okay. We can take heart that this is what God intended: 
 
Alma 32:  
21 And now as I said concerning faith—faith is not to have a perfect knowledge of 
things; therefore if ye have faith ye hope for things which are not seen, which are true. 
 
I love this scripture. Because it is an assurance that we in fact do not see God 
the Father, Jesus Christ, or the Holy Ghost. We don’t see the gold plates, ancient 
prophets, or biblical miracles. 
 
I want to take that a step further. I think more and more people are 
understandably concerned about certain gospel topics. So I’ll modify the scripture a bit: 
 
“Therefore if you have faith you hope for things which are not seen and seem kinda 
crazy to believe, which are true” 
 
There are numerous perfectly logical reasons to not believe in Jesus Christ and 
his Gospel.  
 
I’m sure you can each quickly think of five gospel related things that don’t make 
sense to you, or you have issues with. Perhaps you have wrestled with questions about 
polygamy, or tithing, or maybe a church leader has said something that really upset you, 
and you are told you have to sustain that leader. (Like can you give a talk)

stled with questions about 
polygamy, or tithing, or maybe a church leader has said something that really upset you, 
and you are told you have to sustain that leader. (Like can you give a talk) 
 
 Someone I talked to just a month ago told me that she believed the law of 
Moses was all an apostasy, and that if it was truly inspired by God, it would change her 
opinion of him. 
 
Ultimately it doesn’t make a lot of logical sense to believe a humble jewish 
preacher from 2000 years ago was murdered, brought himself back to life, and because 
of that we will all live a life after death.

Why
 
 
Why make this point? Why point out how “crazy” this all is. It’s to emphasize that 
we do not get argued into believing the gospel is true. 
So if believing in the gospel goes against our natural rational mind. Why do you 
believe?  
 
It is through the spirit, speaking to our spirit that we have evidence of the gospel. 
I fondly call my spiritual side, the irrational side. I can’t use it in an argument to 
prove anything. Rather, it is personal to me. 
 
 When people talk about why they believe in the Gospel, they often talk about 
spiritual experiences. Can you think of a time when you felt the spirit strongly testify to 
you? 
 
 As a missionary we would read Moroni 10 verse 4 to our investigators: 
 
Moroni 10 
4 And when ye shall receive these things, I would exhort you that ye would ask God, 
the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ, if these things are not true; and if ye shall 
ask with a sincere heart, with real intent, having faith in Christ, he will manifest the 
truth of it unto you, by the power of the Holy Ghost.
 
 
I had one investigator on my mission named Damon. He was a veteran of the 
second Iraq war. Understandably he had a lot of heavy things he carried with him. He’d 
closed himself off from praying, and chose to stop believing in Jesus Christ.  
When we went over to his house we read the Book of Mormon or watched a 
general conference talk. For a long time he refused to pray. Little by little the spirit spoke 
to him. 
One day we went over to his house, and he had the biggest smile on his face. He 
let us know that he’d prayed like Moroni ha

a long time he refused to pray. Little by little the spirit spoke 
to him. 
One day we went over to his house, and he had the biggest smile on his face. He 
let us know that he’d prayed like Moroni had told him to, and he’d received confirmation 
that it was true. 
These experiences serve as a start of a life of believing in the gospel. The spirit 
visits the heart of the earnest seeker of truth to plant the seed of belief. 
 
If you’ve felt something like this you know how amazing it is. I have on a couple 
occasions. However we cannot behave like a dog that would wander off and get lost if 
not for the leash of the spirit. The burning of the bosom wears off. Things get hard. We 
start questioning, “Did I really feel the spirit, or was I just caught up in the moment?”

Afterall, Laman and Lemuel saw an angel and still decided to rebel against God.  
 
Oliver Cowdry received a spiritual witness,
 “Did I not speak peace to your mind 
concer[n]ing the matter?—What greater witness can you have than from God? ... 
Doubt not, fear not.” 
 
And yet for a time he was excommunicated from the church. 
 
Despite any spiritual experience you will be confronted with something that tests 
your faith. Remember it’s part of our nature. There is something out there that could 
convince you to leave your faith behind, if you let it. 
 
In the end, our belief comes down to a choice. “Will I choose to stay? Will I 
choose to believe in him?”  
How 
How then do we choose to believe? I think Alma 32 is an excellent tutorial on the 
subject, so I’ll read some more of it:  
 
27 But behold, if ye will awake and arouse your faculties, even to an experiment upon 
my words, and exercise a particle of faith, yea, even if ye can no more than desire to 
believe, let this desire work in you, even until ye believe in a manner that ye can give 
place for a portion of my words. 
28 Now, we will compare the word unto a seed. Now, if ye give place, that a seed may 
be planted in your heart, behold, if it be a true seed, or a good seed, if ye do not cast it 
out by your unbelief, that ye will resist the Spirit of the Lord, behold, it will begin to 
swell within your breasts; and when you feel these swelling motions, ye will begin to 
say within yourselves—It must needs be that this is a good seed, or that the word is 
good, for it beginneth to enlarge my soul; yea, it beginn

when you feel these swelling motions, ye will begin to 
say within yourselves—It must needs be that this is a good seed, or that the word is 
good, for it beginneth to enlarge my soul; yea, it beginneth to enlighten my 
understanding, yea, it beginneth to be delicious to me. 
29 Now behold, would not this increase your faith? I say unto you, Yea; nevertheless 
it hath not grown up to a perfect knowledge. 
 
This is what I referred to before about receiving a spiritual answer to prayer like my 
investigator Damon did.

37 And behold, as the tree beginneth to grow, ye will say: Let us nourish it with great 
care, that it may get root, that it may grow up, and bring forth fruit unto us. And now 
behold, if ye nourish it with much care it will get root, and grow up, and bring forth 
fruit. 
 
We choose to believe by obeying the commandments. When we obey commandments 
we nourish the tree. 
 
15   Beware of false prophets, which come to you in sheep’s clothing, but inwardly 
they are ravening wolves. 
16 Ye shall know them by their fruits. Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of 
thistles? 
17 Even so every good tree bringeth forth good fruit; but a corrupt tree bringeth forth 
evil fruit. 
18 A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good 
fruit. 
19 Every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire. 
20 Wherefore by their fruits ye shall know them. 
 
Think to yourself: “Okay, had my initial testimony building experience (or are waiting for 
it) I chose to plant the seed and obey the commandments. I saw the tree grow, now 
what?” 
 
What are the fruits of you obeying the commandments? 
 
22 But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, 
faith, 
23 Meekness, temperance 
 
Think right now. Have you felt these things in your life? Have you noticed their absence 
at times?  
 
I can testify that when I obey the commandments, those fruits are abundant in my life. I 
may have questions about gospel topics. Things may just not make sense. But I can’t 
deny how the gospel makes me fee

estify that when I obey the commandments, those fruits are abundant in my life. I 
may have questions about gospel topics. Things may just not make sense. But I can’t 
deny how the gospel makes me feel. 
 
 They aren’t as dramatic or noticeable as an initial testimony starting experience. 
Instead they are a sweet peace that comes with every day I obey.

I’ll conclude with a brief summary of my thoughts. 
● It is up to us to choose to believe in Jesus Christ and his gospel. 
● We should not be surprised when our rational brains have a question, or doubt 
as it is in our nature to question. We don’t believe because the gospel makes a 
good argument, but rather because the spirit testifies to our spirits. 
● We choose to believe by keeping the commandments. 
● We are blessed with the fruits of the spirit when we keep the commandments.
